title: International Law
description: Test your knowledge of the rules and treaties that govern relations between nations

questions.question: The Geneva Conventions, which set standards for the treatment of war victims, were most recently updated in which year?
What is the principle of 'sovereignty' in international law?
options: Larger countries have more legal rights
Each state has supreme authority within its own territory
All nations must follow a single set of laws
The United Nations can override national laws

questions.question: The Law of the Sea convention (UNCLOS) establishes that a country's territorial waters extend how far from its coastline?
Which international tribunal was established to prosecute those responsible for the Rwandan genocide?
The concept of 'diplomatic immunity' protects diplomats from what?
options: Prosecution under the host country's laws

questions.question: Hugo Grotius, a Dutch jurist, is often called the 'father' of what field?
The Rome Statute of 1998 established which permanent international court?
What does 'jus cogens' refer to in international law?
options: Peremptory norms that cannot be violated by any nation
Laws that only apply during wartime

questions.question: The Hague Conventions of 1899 and 1907 primarily addressed what?
An 'extradition treaty' allows countries to do what?
options: Transfer accused or convicted persons to face justice in another country

questions.question: The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT), aimed at preventing the spread of nuclear weapons, went into effect in which year?
What is the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) that extends 200 nautical miles from a country's coast?
options: An area closed to all shipping
An area where military operations are prohibited
An area where only that country can fish and exploit resources
An area designated for environmental protection only

questions.question: The Refugee Convention of 1951 defines a refugee as someone who has fled their country due to what?
The Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC) bans the production and use of chemical weapons. When did it enter into force?
What is 'customary international law'?
options: Laws written by the United Nations
Practices accepted as legal obligations through consistent state practice and belief
Laws that only apply to developing nations
